content: How can I help you today?
I'm not sure, honestly. My wife thought it was a good idea for me to talk to someone, so here I am. Things at home just feel overwhelming, and I don't even know where to start.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like things have been a bit heavy for you lately. It’s great that you’re here and open to talking, even if you’re not sure where to start. Maybe we can start with whatever has been weighing on your mind the most recently. What's been feeling overwhelming for you?

A lot of it is about my son. He's been having all these behavioral problems lately, and my wife and I are completely at a loss on how to help him. It's putting so much strain on us, and it feels like we're failing as parents.

That sounds really tough—you're dealing with a lot, both as a parent and as a partner. It seems like you're feeling a strong responsibility to help your son, but also feeling the weight of how it’s affecting your family. What do you think has been the hardest part of this for you?

Honestly, it's feeling powerless. No matter what we try, nothing seems to make a difference with my son, and it's like I'm failing him. On top of that, it feels like my marriage is crumbling under the stress, which just adds to everything. I don't know how to fix any of it.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now—trying to help your son, feeling responsible for your family, and also facing that worry about your marriage. That sense of powerlessness can be so frustrating, especially when you want so badly to make things better. What keeps you going through all of this?

I guess what keeps me going is the hope that somehow, we can figure this out. I don’t want to give up on my son, my wife, or my family. Despite how hard everything feels, I still want us to stay together and get through this.

That hope and determination say a lot about how much you care for your family, even in the face of all these challenges. It’s clear that your commitment runs deep, and that’s something really meaningful to hold onto. What do you think might help lighten even a little bit of the load right now?
I honestly don’t know. I feel like I’ve already tried everything I could think of. Maybe understanding how to support my son better would help, but I don’t even know where to start with that anymore.

It sounds like you're feeling stuck but still really want to find a way to better support your son. That willingness to keep searching for solutions—even when it feels like you've tried everything—shows so much strength and love as a parent. What have you tried in the past that’s worked even a little, or that you feel has brought you closer to understanding him?

I honestly can’t think of much that has worked. We’ve tried setting stricter boundaries, being more understanding, talking to him calmly, even some outside advice, but nothing seems to stick. Every time we think we’re making progress, something happens, and it feels like we’re right back where we started. It’s exhausting.

It can feel so discouraging when it seems like no matter what you do, things go back to where they started. You’ve clearly been putting in so much effort, trying different approaches, and not giving up on your son—and that takes a lot of perseverance, even when it feels exhausting. What do you think your son might need most from you and your wife right now?

I’m not sure. I want to believe he needs us to be there for him, to understand him, but it’s hard when we don’t even know what’s behind his behavior. Maybe he needs something we’re just not giving him, and that thought is really overwhelming. It’s hard to not feel like I’m failing him.

It’s clear how much you want to be there for your son and understand what he’s going through, even when it’s so overwhelming. Feeling like you’re not sure what he needs—or worrying you’re not giving enough—must be weighing heavily on you. Have there been any moments, even small ones, where you’ve felt a connection with him or a sense of what might be going on for him?

I honestly can't think of any recent moments like that. It feels like there's this wall between us, and no matter how hard I try to reach him, I just can't break through. I want to connect with him, but it’s like he’s drifting further away, and I don’t know how to pull him back.

That sense of distance must be so painful, especially when you’re trying so hard to reach out and connect. From what you've shared, it's clear just how much you care—it’s not easy to keep trying when it feels like there’s a wall. What do you think he might be feeling, or trying to tell you, through his behavior?

That’s the thing—I don’t know what he’s trying to tell us. Sometimes it seems like he’s angry at the world, or maybe even at us, but I don’t know why. Other times, he just shuts down and won’t say anything at all. It’s like I’m constantly guessing, and I’m always getting it wrong.

Not knowing how to interpret his behavior must be incredibly frustrating and leave you feeling lost at times. It sounds like you're really trying to understand his emotions, even when it feels like you're grasping in the dark. What do you think might help you get a clearer sense of what’s going on for him?

Maybe talking to someone who has experience with kids like him could help—someone who might understand what he’s going through better than I do. But honestly, the idea of involving someone else feels a little intimidating. Do you think that’s something I should do?

It’s natural to feel hesitant about involving someone else, especially when this is so personal and close to your heart. At the same time, it sounds like you're open to the idea of seeking help for the sake of your son and your family. If you feel ready, reaching out to someone experienced with kids, like a counselor or therapist, might give you new tools and insights to support him—and you don’t have to face this alone. How do you feel when you think about taking that step?
